author: Brandon Schwartz
bottom_line: Varying amounts of snow surface refreeze occurred last night and were weakest in the southern half of the forecast area. For travel in avalanche terrain today, get an early start this morning and exit avalanche terrain before the snow surface becomes unsupportable. Deep wet snow or signs of unstable wet snow such as rollerballs or pinwheels indicate that wet loose avalanches could occur.
hazard_discussion:
• Observers reported another round of wet loose avalanches and recent cornice failures yesterday.
  • Some glide cracks have formed on steep slopes in rocky areas. Like cornices, the exact timing of glide crack avalanches is notoriously difficult to predict. Avoiding travel on or under slopes with glide cracks represents the best course of action.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Some locations, mainly in the northern half of the forecast area received a decent snow surface refreeze last night for the first time in several days. Areas in the southern half of the forecast area where air temperatures remained above freezing last night are likely to have a thinner and more superficial snow surface refreeze that was heavily reliant on the nighttime radiational cooling of the snowpack. Regardless of location, once the snow surface refreeze from last night melts away, deeper residual wet snow from the last several days will be exposed. This will bring about the possibility of more wet loose avalanches. Some of these avalanches could be large enough to cause problems for backcountry travelers, especially on long slopes where a wet loose avalanche will entrain more snow as it travels downhill. 

Once the snow surface becomes unsupportable it is time to think about avoiding slopes steeper than about 35 degrees. Pinwheels, rollerballs, sinking into ankle-deep wet snow when you step off your sled or skis, and wet loose avalanches are all signs of unstable wet snow. If your desire is to travel in avalanche terrain today, get an early start and exit avalanche terrain before signs of deep or unstable wet snow develop.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wet Loose
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wet Loose avalanches are the release of wet unconsolidated snow or slush. These avalanches typically occur within layers of wet snow near the surface of the snowpack, but they may quickly gouge into lower snowpack layers. Like Loose Dry Avalanches, they start at a point and entrain snow as they move downhill, forming a fan-shaped avalanche. Other names for loose-wet avalanches include point-release avalanches or sluffs. Loose Wet avalanches can trigger slab avalanches that break into deeper snow layers.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
More natural cornice failures were reported yesterday following several days of prolonged warm weather with little to no overnight refreeze. While some areas received a decent snow surface refreeze last night, cornice failures remain possible today once last nights refreeze melts away. Large to massive blocks of snow falling off of overhung sections along ridgetops could cause problems on their own or trigger wet snow avalanches on the slopes below.

Most cornice fall accidents occur during ridgetop travel and take the party involved by surprise. Stay well back from cornice edges, keeping exposed rocks or trees between you and the cornice edge. Consider avoiding travel on slopes below cornices.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Cornice Fall
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Cornice Fall is the release of an overhanging mass of snow that forms as the wind moves snow over a sharp terrain feature, such as a ridge, and deposits snow on the downwind (leeward) side. Cornices range in size from small wind drifts of soft snow to large overhangs of hard snow that are 30 feet (10 meters) or taller. They can break off the terrain suddenly and pull back onto the ridge top and catch people by surprise even on the flat ground above the slope. Even small cornices can have enough mass to be destructive and deadly. Cornice Fall can entrain loose surface snow or trigger slab avalanches.
